title: 103_hr2396
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the financial records for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Individuals can seek civil damages against a state if their financial records are disclosed unlawfully by a state officer or employee. Individuals can bring a civil action for damages against a State in a US district court for unauthorized disclosure of financial records. No liability if disclosure was made in good faith but erroneously interpreted. Damages in such cases include $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure or actual damages sustained plus additional penalties for willful disclosure. The plaintiff can take legal action against a State for unauthorized disclosure of financial records, with damages including $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure or actual damages, punitive damages for willful disclosure, and the costs of the action. Definitions for "depository institution" and "financial record" are provided in this section. The term "financial record" is defined in accordance with the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a State agency that manages child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies have access to and can use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer according to state laws. The agency must provide written notice to the consumer before obtaining the report and certify that the requirements have been fulfilled. State child support enforcement agencies must certify fulfillment of requirements before accessing consumer reports for child support obligations. A State child support enforcement agency is defined as an agency administering a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders as mandated by the Social Security Act. It outlines procedures for ensuring coverage of health care costs for children in accordance with state guidelines and expediting the resolution of noncompliance allegations. The Social Security Act mandates the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders. States must establish guidelines for covering health care costs of children under these orders, meeting minimum standards set by the Secretary. Regulations will outline the contents of such orders for health care coverage. The State must establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders, including the contents of the order, distribution of responsibility, insurance provision and claims, denial of coverage, penalties for non-compliance, and consideration of changing circumstances. The State must establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders, considering the best interests of the child, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to issue proposed and final regulations within specific timeframes to implement the amendments related to this subsection. Health and Human Services will issue final regulations to implement amendments related to the enforcement of support orders requiring absent parents to obtain health insurance for their children. The amount of support collected will be based on the savings to the State from providing health insurance to the children, following a health insurance savings methodology adopted by the State. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations to implement amendments related to enforcing support orders for absent parents to provide health insurance for their children. A study will be conducted to determine incentives for States to ensure noncustodial parents pay for children's health expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit the results of a study to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee regarding enforcing support orders for absent parents to provide health insurance for their children. SEC. 5 amends the Social Security Act to include compliance with time limits for child support assistance. SEC. 6 requires employers to withhold wages for child support and imposes penalties for late payments. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to make timely payments for child support wages or face a $1,000 penalty to the State. Penalties collected must be used for the State plan approved under section 454. Effective immediately upon enactment, applies to wages paid thereafter. The amendment to the Social Security Act requires timely payments for child support wages, with penalties for non-compliance. State plans approved under section 454 must meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments. If state legislation is needed, a delay is permitted until after the 1st calendar quarter following the state legislature session. In a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing states to locate absent parents for child support enforcement and visitation orders by accessing records from other states and federal sources. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network to locate absent parents for child support enforcement and visitation orders by accessing records from other states and federal sources. The network allows for on-line and batch processing of locate requests, with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information to be broadcast and returned to a requesting State. Ready access to courts is provided by locating a computer terminal in each court. The bill HR 2396 IH aims to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network for locating absent parents for child support enforcement and visitation orders. It allows for online and batch processing of locate requests with a 48-hour turnaround time.
